intro: Hebecladus granulosus, commonly known as the granular hebecladus, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is native to New Zealand and thrives in moist, shaded environments, often found in forest understories. The plant features finely divided, fern-like leaves that are covered in a distinctive granular texture, giving it a unique appearance. Its small, white to pale yellow flowers bloom in clusters, attracting pollinators such as bees and flies. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in its native range.
